intro: Ipomopsis spicata var. cephaloidea, commonly known as the mountain beardplant, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its tall, spindly stems and clusters of blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and open habitats, such as slopes and meadows. Its flowers are tubular and attract pollinators like hummingbirds and butterflies. The variety cephaloidea is distinguished by its more compact growth habit and dense flowering heads compared to the typical form.
